::: {.question} **Disposition Effect and Taxes — Brazilian Threshold ** **Context (read this first):** In Brazil, stock sales are **tax-exempt** if your **total proceeds from stock sales in the month** are **≤ BRL 20,000**. If your monthly proceeds **exceed BRL 20,000**, then **all capital gains realized that month** are taxed at **15%**. (Losses do not trigger tax and can typically be used to offset gains, but here we focus only on **today’s cash** to make the comparison clean.) This exercise compares two end-of-month choices to raise cash: - **Sell the winner (a position with a gain)** vs. **Sell the loser (a position with a loss)** - We deliberately set **the same proceeds (S)** for both sales so that any difference in **after-tax cash** comes **only from taxes** (not from different sale sizes). - This connects to the **disposition effect**: investors often prefer selling winners (to “lock in gains”) and holding losers (to avoid realizing losses), but that behaviour can be **tax-inefficient** when the threshold is binding. You will: 1) compute **after-tax cash** if you sell the winner, 2) compute **after-tax cash** if you sell the loser, 3) compute the **advantage** (loser − winner). If **S > 20,000**, selling the winner may incur tax **today**, while selling the loser does **not**. ``` Warning: package 'knitr' was built under R version 4.2.3 ```
Leg Proceeds (BRL) Basis (BRL) Gain/Loss (BRL) Tax (BRL)
Sell winner (gain) 24243 16407 7836 1175.4
Sell loser (loss) 24243 32440 -8197 0
**Assumptions:** One sale in the month, no other offsets, ignore costs; FIFO implicit. **Rule:** If **monthly proceeds** from stock sales **> BRL 20,000**, **all gains** that month are taxed at **15%**; otherwise, **exempt**. ::: {.question-block}
✅ Step-by-step (winner leg with a gain)
• Check the threshold: Monthly proceeds = 24243. Condition: S > 20,000 ⇒ gains are taxable at 15%.
• Compute tax on the gain (if taxable): Gain = S − basis = 24243 − 16407 = 7836. Tax = 15% × Gain = 0.15 × 7836 = 1175.4 BRL. (If the line above shows 0, it means the sale is **exempt** in this scenario.)
• After-tax cash today: Proceeds − Tax = 24243 − 1175.4 = 23067.6 BRL.

Why this matters: If the threshold binds, selling a winner creates **immediate tax outflow**, reducing today’s cash.
::: ::: {.question-block}
✅ Step-by-step (loser leg with a loss)
• Tax on losses: Realizing a loss does not trigger capital gains tax now; the tax due on this sale is 0 BRL. • After-tax cash today: Proceeds − Tax = 24243 − 0 = 24243 BRL.

Why this matters: Selling the loser yields the **same gross cash** as selling the winner in this setup, but with **no tax haircut** today. (Separately from this exercise, a realized loss may be used to offset gains in the month/year depending on the rules in force.)
::: ::: {.question-block}
✅ Interpret and connect to investor behavior
Because **proceeds are equal** (S for both legs), the difference in after-tax cash is **purely the tax** on the winner (if any):
• Advantage = After-tax(loser) − After-tax(winner) = 24243 − 23067.6 = 1175.4 BRL.
• If S > 20,000, then Advantage = the winner’s tax amount.

Key intuition (disposition effect): Many investors feel tempted to **sell winners** and **hold losers**. Under the Brazilian threshold rule, when **S > 20,000**, selling the winner can be **tax-inefficient today** (you pay 15% on the gain), whereas selling the loser gives you the **same cash** without a tax haircut. This illustrates how **tax rules** and **behavioral biases** interact: sticking to “sell what went up” may **reduce** your **net cash today**, even if it feels psychologically rewarding.
::: :::
